data.source: General Social Survey (GSS) special science module
data.access_details: Publicly available GSS data (access through NORC)
data.notes: Data pooled across three waves; science module items combined with standard GSS variables.

method.description: The study pools three waves of the U.S. General Social Survey and applies latent class analysis to identify distinct religio-scientific perspectives, followed by regression models to examine sociodemographic predictors and the association of class membership with political attitudes.
steps: Pool the 2006, 2008, and 2010 GSS waves containing the special science module.
Select items measuring science knowledge, science attitudes, and religious beliefs.
Estimate latent class models with varying numbers of classes and compare fit using BIC and the Lo-Mendell-Rubin likelihood-ratio test.
Choose the three-class solution (Traditional, Modern, Post-Secular) based on statistical fit and theoretical justification.
Assign respondents to classes based on posterior probabilities.
Run multinomial logistic regression to predict class membership from sociodemographic variables (e.g., religious tradition, gender, race, education, income, ideology).

Estimate binary and ordinal logistic regression models to relate class membership to political attitudes toward abortion rights, stem-cell research, genetically modified food, and energy policy, controlling for sociodemographics.
method.models: Latent Class Analysis; Multinomial Logistic Regression; Binary and Ordinal Logistic Regression
method.outcome_variable: Latent class membership and policy attitudes (abortion rights, stem-cell research funding, GMO food regulation, energy policy preferences)
method.independent_variables: Science knowledge items, science attitude items, religious belief indicators, religiosity measures, sociodemographic characteristics
method.control_variables: Gender, race/ethnicity, education, income, class, age, religious service attendance, political ideology

results.summary: Latent class analysis identifies three perspectives on science and religion: Traditional (43% of respondents), Modern (36%), and Post-Secular (21%). Traditional respondents show low science literacy and high religiosity; Modern respondents show high science literacy and low religiosity; Post-Secular respondents combine high science literacy with strong religious commitment but reject specific scientific explanations such as the Big Bang. Sociodemographic patterns reveal that women, African Americans, Latinos, and lower social classes are overrepresented in the Traditional class, while conservatives and frequent churchgoers are more likely to be Post-Secular. Political attitude models show that Post-Secular respondents are the most opposed to abortion rights and to public funding for stem-cell research, whereas Modern respondents are most supportive. These effects persist when controlling for religious tradition, ideology, and other demographics, indicating that religio-scientific perspectives independently shape policy attitudes.

numerical_results.outcome_name: Difference in abortion-rights support (Post-Secular vs. Traditional)
